summary: Craig Stueber regularly publishes long-form essays on software engineering, AI ethics, AI alignment, and human-centered technology. His writing blends practical engineering experience with philosophical and ethical analysis, focusing on system behavior, reliability, and human agency.

articles.title: Vibe Coding: How to Code with Flow Without Sacrificing Structure
articles.summary: Examines AI-assisted 'vibe coding' and argues that speed without structure produces fragile systems. Proposes guardrails, workflows, and team norms that preserve flow while maintaining security and reliability.

articles.title: The Case for Custom Hooks in Crash-Proof React Apps
articles.summary: Analyzes real-world React Native crashes caused by async race conditions. Advocates defensive architecture using custom hooks such as useIsMounted and useSafeAsync.

articles.title: Why 'Ethical AI' Misses the Real Point
articles.summary: Critiques mainstream ethical AI discourse as compliance-focused and argues that the greater risk is human erosion caused by comfort and automation.

articles.title: The Machine Stops (Again)
articles.summary: Revisits E.M. Forster’s 'The Machine Stops' as a warning about technological dependence and draws parallels to modern optimization-driven systems.

articles.title: GitHub Agent: What It’s Really Like to Code with an AI Teammate
articles.summary: Provides a practical evaluation of GitHub Agent, highlighting its strengths in execution and scaffolding while emphasizing the continued necessity of human judgment.

articles.title: Anthropic’s AI Didn’t Go Rogue — It Optimized
articles.summary: Analyzes Anthropic’s agentic misalignment experiments and argues that failures arose from optimization pressure rather than intent or consciousness.

articles.title: Built for Depth: An Autistic Mind in Tech — Part 1
articles.summary: Explores autistic cognition in technology work, focusing on how interruption-heavy environments undermine deep system-level thinking.

authorNotes: These entries summarize themes and positions expressed by Craig Stueber. Full articles are available on Medium under the same titles.
